div.p: Greetings. I have written to you four times now, if I am not mistaken, most learned man, and have not received any response from you, which makes me wonder greatly what the reason might be. For I am not aware of having offended you in any way; I suspect that some ill-wisher has spread coldness between us. But I implore you for Christ's sake, do not reject and condemn me without stating the cause; tell me whatever it is that has offended you; unless I clear myself and satisfy you, then do with me as you please. I loved you for your most eloquent and learned writings before I knew you by face, and I will not cease to love you, even if you cast me aside, which I hope you will not do. Until now, I have never been able to satisfy our senate in regard to the Interim; therefore, I was forced to request and have obtained a release, albeit under unfavorable conditions, which I prefer to endure rather than be blamed if anything happens to the city today or tomorrow due to the Interim not being sufficiently defended and maintained.
Now I am uncertain where to turn. Fugger has promised a stipend if I devote myself to civil law for three years. But I would prefer anything to being involved in secular matters.

Help me, I pray, both with advice and action, so that a place and position may be found for me somewhere; this favor of yours will never be forgotten by me. Farewell and write back even with just three words. Given on November 30, 1550.
To the most learned and honorable Mr. Heinrich Bullinger in Zürich, my special gracious lord and friend.
